thread.title: Petitionfor Barcelona and PSG to replay remarkable Champions League match builds momentum
thread.title_full: Petitionfor Barcelona and PSG to replay remarkable Champions League match builds momentum

author: Mick Gadd
title: Petitionfor Barcelona and PSG to replay remarkable Champions League match builds momentum
text:
Petitionfor Barcelona and PSG to replay remarkable Champions League match builds momentum Share Referee Deniz Aytekin dishes out a yellow card during his controversial performance (Photo: REUTERS) Share Get FC Barcelona updates directly to your inbox + Subscribe Thank you for subscribing! Could not subscribe, try again later Invalid Email 
Barcelona's 6-1 triumph over Paris Saint-Germain has been lauded among the greatest ever football comebacks but the enthusiasm isn't shared by everyone. 
A petition to force the match to be replayed because of the performance of referee Deniz Aytekin has soared over 130,000 signatures. 
Barca were all but out of the Champions League as they welcomed PSG to the Nou Camp trailing 4-0 from the first leg. 
The hosts led 3-0 before a valuable Edinson Cavani away goal appeared to ruin their hopes of an epic comeback. Read More Barcelona players celebrate in the dressing room after their amazing comeback against PSG (Photo: Instagram/mascherano14) Barca's Sergi Roberto is swamped by team-mates after scoring the winner (Photo: REUTERS) 
However, with the benefit of a second penalty and a last-ditch finish from Sergi Roberto secured a 6-5 aggregate result. 
But while many celebrated the remarkable achievement of the Catalans to reach the quarter-final under such duress, Luis Melendo Olmedo isn't having it. 
He started the petition, claiming: "Incidents that seriously damaged PSG. As a result of the German referee Deniz Aytekin, who gave Barcelona an advantage with his refereeing decisions." Read More 
He goes so far as to list the controversial decisions of the referee in his reasonings, which can be read here , with varying degrees of merit. 
In his first petition on Change.org, Olmedo's target of 150,000 supporters appears to have lacked ambition. Like us on Facebook
